    Head S (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [17th May, 2002],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head S of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Yeo Guat Kwang].

    Question again proposed.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, first, I want to take up what the Manpower Minister said yesterday about the proposed CPF cut for workers above 40. He argued that it should not be viewed as introducing age discrimination. He pointed out, rightly, that the CPF rate for workers above 55 was already lower than the rate for younger workers. This is true.

    But, if I recall correctly, the main reason why the CPF rate was lowered for workers above 55 was because the Government wanted to extend the retirement age from 55 to 60, and then to 62. It would be raised to 67 eventually. At that time, 55 is considered the age when all workers would stop work and retire, with zero employment income. And, therefore, it is at this age that they can start withdrawing from their CPF for retirement purposes. In this context, reducing the employer's CPF rate to keep these workers employed past

Column: 1575

55 was considered reasonable, and does not offend our sensibilities. But this is not the case for workers below 55. Many in their 40s are still in their prime, and still saving for their retirement years. To cut the CPF rate of workers between 40 and 55 is to send the unintended signal to the market that this group of workers can be discriminated against.

    Sir, many unemployed people above 40 say that they find it very hard to re-enter the job market because of age discrimination at the hiring process. This is a very serious issue for middle-aged and older workers, a barrier that cannot be removed simply by offering more job-matching schemes or excellent training programmes. Older job seekers who cannot find work because their wage expectations are too high can learn to reduce their expectations. Those who lack the required skills can retrain. In both cases, they can adapt and find work. But in the case of an age barrier, older job seekers have no recourse, no matter how willing they are to adapt. If this problem is not addressed, it will become even more severe in time, as our population continues to age.

    Sir, just last week, an employer came to see me to seek my help in getting 20 work permits for foreign workers to work at his food stalls all around the island. He asked me to write to the Ministry of Manpower. I dutifully did so but, at the same time, I also grilled him about why he did not employ Singaporeans who are out of work. I told him I have many residents who do not have a job and asked if he would consider them. I asked him what were the criteria for the job. Is there an age limit? He said, yes, below 45. He said that frying over a wok requires a lot of energy. I was not persuaded. It so happened that the very next resident who came to see me was looking for a job, any job. He looked strong, he is able, but he is 48. I dashed out of my MPS office, grabbed the employer, who was on his way out, and made him give an on-the-spot interview to this resident. The employer was not obliged to hire this

Column: 1576

older worker, but I think I registered my point with him - older Singaporeans should be given an equal shot at the job.

    Economic growth will not take care of the situation completely, as it has to do with employers' perceptions of the elderly. And it is particularly during a downturn that older workers need extra protection. Is there a mechanism for the Ministry to ensure that employers who apply for work permits do so only after they have trawled from MOM's bank of jobless workers who can do the same job? It is true that even this will not mean that older workers will be hired. But it will send a strong signal to employers that we take seriously our mission of creating jobs for Singaporeans. This is not to discourage employers from hiring foreigners that they need to run their businesses. Rather, it is to encourage them to give Singaporeans an equal chance to get a job. There is a difference in nuance.

    The Minister earlier said that the Ministry had received only a few complaints from older workers regarding age discrimination. He said that in 2000 and 2001, there were four and five complaints respectively.

    The Chairman: Time is running out, Ms Ng.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how these cases were resolved. The only way to fight age discrimination, short of legislating it, is to make clear that our labour mechanisms do not tolerate bias against older workers.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Sir, there are many advantages of flexible work arrangements. Through flexible work arrangements and flexible working hours, other than pro-family and enhancing the employees' welfare, more importantly, such arrangements can actually strengthen the company's competitiveness and workers' employability. On the part of employers, however, it seems that they are pushing for flexibility more on the basis of cost savings. As a labour MP, my view is that, while there may be cost savings, they need not necessarily come from wage cost.

Column: 1577



    One good example is ST Aerospace. ST Aerospace had, with the endorsement of the MOM, implemented a scheme of compensatory time-off. The exercise involved the union very early in the development. It also incorporated safeguards to check against abuse, eg, half yearly reviews to see if the scheme could be improved further. At the same time, there was ample communication to ensure that all workers understood the implications of the changes. Under the scheme, the company releases employees on full pay when they are not needed at work. These employees make up the credited hours and time off from their future overtime. The workers continue to receive regular pay while having flexibility in their time schedules and enjoy more leisure time. The company is now able to improve its competitiveness, with a manpower deployment plan that was more aligned with the job schedule. This enabled it to free up its resources so that it could garner more jobs. The gains in profits arising from this new arrangement were also shared amongst the staff. I am aware that KK Hospital is another good example that also has good flexible work arrangements.

    However, todate, the examples I have cited are the exceptions rather than the norm. Does the Ministry have any plan to amend the legislation to facilitate greater workforce flexibility? I urge the Ministry of Manpower to do more to encourage companies to adopt flexible work patterns and flexible working hour arrangements that will strengthen their competitiveness and enhance their employees' employability and welfare.

    The labour movement will support flexi-work arrangements, provided certain fundamental principles are adhered to. For example, it should not solely be a cost-cutting measure. Rather, it should make the company more productive and the gains must be shared with the workers. We do not want to see a significant swing in the workers' income. Clear guidelines must also be given. I urge the Ministry of Manpower to do more to encourage companies to adopt flexible work patterns and flexible working hours that will strengthen their competitiveness.

Column: 1578



    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Sir, over the last few days, we have heard quite a number of points made about workers being fussy about jobs. Yesterday, the Minister said that there are jobs in the marine and hotel sectors, for instance, but there are no takers because workers are fussy. That may be one perspective. On the other hand, I want to offer another perspective, ie, basically, it is the way the jobs are designed that makes it very difficult for workers to work in these sectors. We seriously need to look at this area of how to redesign jobs for three reasons: one, is the aging workforce; second, the negative image of some sectors; and, third, the need for flexibility to accommodate different life cycle needs.

    Let me just elaborate on the first point, ie, the problem of an aging workforce. If we were to look at the median age of workers, we will notice that it has increased from 33.6 years in 1991 to 37.8 in 2001. The pool of workers aged 40 years and above has also increased by 90%, from 31% in 1991 to 43% in 2001. Clearly, if jobs are still being structured and designed in a way that only take care of the needs of a younger workforce, the older workers will find it very difficult to do the job.

    Let me give an example of a resident who came to see me. She is in her 50s and she is working in a hospital. She told me that her job involves having to take care of 7-8 patients in a day, cleaning them up and bathing them. She feels that, very soon, she will not be able to do that job and she will be sacked, because she will not be able to perform up to standard, as it is a very physically demanding job. In the course of my work, I also came to know of another worker who works in a factory producing TV mainframes. Her job requires her to move the mainframe from one workbench to another workbench for a minimum period of eight hours. She had worked for 10 years, and she said that she does not think she can continue working in that way anymore, because it requires her to stand and to carry these heavy mainframes from one workbench to another. She is really looking forward to the day when she gets retrenched and

Column: 1579

gets her retrenchment benefits, and she can take a break and look for a lighter job more suited for her age.

    Sir, I do not believe that such jobs cannot be redesigned to make it easier for people to work. If we do not look at this issue, and then we make it very difficult for Singaporeans to work and allow employers to tap into an everlasting pool of young foreign workers, there will be no incentives for them to redesign jobs to meet the needs of older Singaporean workers.

    On the second point of image, this is a serious problem because, if we were to look at jobs in the marine sector, it is usually categorised as jobs that attract the three Ds - demanding, dangerous and also dirty. Sir, I do not know whether any Member in this House has gone to a shipyard. But if you have gone to a shipyard, you will really understand what working in a shipyard means in the marine sector. Can we imagine a worker coming for a job interview in a shipyard and, for the first time, looking at the work in the shipyard? Most definitely, the worker will get very frightened and worried. So there is clearly a need for us to try and improve the image of jobs in these sectors which workers do not find attractive at all. For instance, we can say that the safety record in the marine sector has improved considerably, so there is no fear for people to work in the shipyards. Safety is taken care of. There could also be an orientation programme, etc, to get them acclimatised to work in a shipyard. We really have to do a lot more in order to enhance the image of jobs in these sectors.

    My third point is about flexibility - flexibility to take into account the needs of people in different lifecycles. We have heard what the Deputy Prime Minister said a few days ago. He said that we are very much a patriarchal society. Women have to perform certain tasks and we see a lot of women staying at home. But there are still many women who want to come out to work. As the jobs become more

Column: 1580

intermittent and there is less job security, we will find that a lot more women will have to come out to work in order to supplement the family income. If we look at the survey done by the Ministry of Manpower about two years ago, it says that 40% of those women who wanted to go back to work could not go back to work because they said that there was just not enough part-time work. That means that if there is more part-time work available, then, obviously, they would want to come out to work. And it is not just a question of them coming out to work in order that they can buy more ---

    The Chairman: Mdm Halimah, could you complete your third point, please?

    Mdm Halimah Yacob: My point is that there must be a definite attempt and there must be serious efforts made to redesign jobs. And we need to redesign jobs to take care of these three areas: one, the aging workforce; second, to redesign jobs to take care of the poor image in some sectors; and, third, to redesign jobs to enable more women to get into the labour market and, therefore, to supplement the family income.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang: Sir, workers are badly affected when they are retrenched. To help them tide over a difficult situation, it is necessary to give the affected workers some form of retrenchment benefits. Recently, our retrenchment benefit system has come under scrutiny. Are there any weaknesses with the present system? I think the answer is yes, there are. While the law states that those with more than three years of service can claim retrenchment compensation, the payment of such compensation is not mandatory, neither is the sum. Indeed, we know of cases where workers are retrenched without compensation in non-unionised companies.
1.45 pm

    The present system is unfunded, which means no funds are set aside for retrenchment. When the time comes, the company looks for money to pay for these retrenchment benefits. This causes a drain on the company's financial resources, and even

Column: 1581

endangers the jobs of the remaining workers. For example, it is possible that a company is able to pay all the retrenchment benefits to the workers who are laid off first, but yet still finds that it is not viable and ceases operation. The workers who remain after the first round of retrenchment, who may be the better lot, end up with nothing at all.

    Further, as business cycles become shorter, if we stick to the approach that workers with less than three years of service are not entitled to claim any retrenchment benefits at all, we will have problems because there will be more such workers who are under this category, as the job market will get more volatile.

    One possible suggestion put forward by some of the union leaders is an enhanced bonus system. Under the system, the employers and employees put aside a certain amount of money, say, from the performance bonuses when the company is still doing well and in good health. The money is vested in their employees' names over a period of time. It could be in the form of unit trust. Over the years, it will be gradually built up. Then, when the worker is retrenched, the fund can help the worker to tide over financially until he finds a new job. Such an arrangement does not add to the financial burden of a company during retrenchment, and it is portable. The fund can be built up as the worker moves from job to job. In the current system, service with a previous employer does not count for retrenchment benefits.

    I - and I am sure many workers - would like to know the Ministry's thinking with regard to our current retrenchment benefits system, and the practices. Does the Ministry acknowledge these weaknesses? What is the Ministry's thinking on how we are going to improve the system?

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, it looks like the days of full employment are over. Like all developed economies, we may have to accept that there will always be some form of structural unemployment, because there is a mismatch between the skills of laid-off

Column: 1582

workers and the skills requirements of new job openings.

    Indeed, it has been forecasted by many economists that the longer term natural rate of unemployment in Singapore will rise to about 4%-5%. Sir, if this rate stays or increases in the long run, there could be an increasing burden on society.

    A possible way out is to look into having some form of unemployment insurance for workers or for employees in general. This would help the unemployed workers tide over temporarily, whilst they seek retraining or alternative employment. Sir, for the private sector to run such an unemployment scheme alone without it being made compulsory by law for all employees may not be economically viable, as there is a lack of economies of scale and the problem of what is often called in the insurance industry "adverse selection", in that only those most at risk would take up this form of insurance. Those who have relatively secure jobs, like in the civil service, would not take up.

    The scheme could be similar to the concept of Medisave or medical insurance where individuals may be mandated by law to contribute, say, 2-3% of their CPF contribution towards an unemployment insurance scheme. Since all employees will have to contribute on their account to this scheme, it can also be administered privately, instead of being State run. An unemployed individual may draw on these balances and the insurance for a period of time to help him meet his or her financial obligations during this period.

    Sir, we could prevent abuse of the scheme by, say, tying the payment of unemployment benefits during this period to skills training or retraining and/or active job search. In this way, we could avoid inadvertently promoting the welfare state mentality and the disincentives to work.

    Sir, I see the introduction of this kind of unemployment insurance as a possible extension of our CPF scheme, ie, to expand the coverage of our social security to meet unforeseen unemployment circumstances. This is also in line with our

Column: 1583

plan to encourage greater self-sufficiency and responsibility for individuals, whilst catering for a real and possible need in the future, in view of globalisation and our changing domestic economy.

    I would, therefore, like to ask the Minister if his Ministry has conducted any studies on unemployment insurance and, if so, whether he would consider introducing some form of unemployment insurance scheme, similar to the Medisave scheme, through the CPF.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, the global economic slowdown has played havoc with the lives of our people. As several of my fellow hon. Members had earlier recounted, many of the residents, like those of mine, lost their jobs and came to seek our help to find another job, and to tide over a very difficult and traumatic period in their lives.

    Not all of them were doing low-skilled work, a group whose plight many of my fellow colleagues have focused on. Some were holding skills and technical positions, while others held managerial positions. While their immediate needs - feeding their family and paying household bills are indeed pressing - what I am equally, in truth, more concerned with is whether the jobs that were lost would ever return, even when the economy recovers. Some will never return, having permanently migrated from our shores. New jobs will be created. But, at the same time, some skills would have become redundant and obsolete. How are our people going to cope in a world that has changed so abruptly?

    I would like to join my fellow hon. colleagues to ask the Minister the following questions. How many jobs were lost since 2001 when the slowdown began? If we were to classify the jobs that were lost as low-skilled, skilled and technical and managerial, how many would there be in each category? How many of the jobs that were lost are lost permanently? What are the job prospects for this year? How many new jobs will be

Column: 1584

created? Finally, how many of the new jobs will be filled by Singaporeans or permanent residents? What is holding our people from the rest of the new jobs? What is being done to help our people to overcome the obstacles to these jobs?

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Aljunied)(In Malay): Sir, providing assistance to residents to look for jobs is the most important talk of the CDC at present. Our experience shows that it is not an easy task. Many are still waiting and hoping for assistance but they are disappointed. The number of those who are assisted has been increasing but is still under 20%. This is a serious problem and MOM should continue to help with greater effort. I have found that there are many more job mismatches than job matches.

    With your indulgence, Mr Chairman, I would like to give two examples that I had experienced. A 45-year-old father of two school-going children used to receive a salary of $4,200 and did not want any other job except in the manufacturing sector. We had suggested that he work in the IT sector with a salary of $3,500 but he refused because he said he liked the experience and the skill that he had learnt from the manufacturing sector. The job that he had lost will never come back.

    Another person, an Eurasian who used to get $3,600 had been retrenched. He tried to apply for many jobs, by the hundreds but was not successful. Finally, he said that he was a victim of discrimination because he came from the "others" group. I have always heard many Malays saying that they were discriminated against because of language or race, but this is the first time that I heard of a person being discriminated for being under "others". Actually, he had a colleague at the same place, a Chinese, who did not get an alternative job. I convinced him that his case was not a question of discrimination because his Chinese friend also faced the same problem. Finally, he and his friend agreed to attend a diploma course on Freight Management with funding under the Northeast CDC's surrogate scheme.

Column: 1585



    There is still the problem of people being too choosy in finding jobs but there are still employers who are also choosy in selecting workers, especially those 45 years and above.

    Finally, Mr Chairman, in the past, you could still get hawker stalls. Presently, there is no such opportunity as everything is done by tender. The opportunity to open a stall in the school canteen is also lesser. So what is the fate of such individuals? It is true that the only way out is to go for training and retraining. But I must say that this process takes a long time and it is a difficult task due to the mindset of the workers and the employers. As we try to convince others to go for retraining, MOM should cooperate with ENV to find out ways to provide new job opportunities, which include hawking and setting up small businesses for more workers who have been retrenched and might be difficult to be retrained in the short-term.

    The Minister of State for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Sir, Members have expressed concern regarding the welfare of our workers especially in this downturn. We also share this concern. Mr Hawazi was worried that employers, in view of their difficulties, might be quick on the mark to dismiss their workforce. Sir, the law, specifically the Employment Act, protests against unfair dismissal, and MOM reiterates that workers who have been unfairly dismissed or denied their benefits should inform my Ministry. We will investigate, seek appropriate remedies and compensation. Nevertheless, Mr Hawazi will be heartened to note that unfair dismissals in the last three years, at least those reported to MOM, were stable - 32 last year, compared to 29 in the year 2000 and 33 the year before.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked what about the plight of retrenched workers. In this regard, let me applaud the unions' efforts. Our data shows that many retrenched workers in unionised companies were paid reasonable sums of retrenchment benefits, while those who were non-unionised were reported to have received little or no retrenchment benefits. Mr Yeo suggests an enhanced bonus system

Column: 1586

where a proportion of the company's profits is put aside and built up over the years to be utilised when workers get retrenched. It is a good idea, but may be better encouraged on a voluntary basis, rather than through Government intervention. Unions and employers could negotiate for such arrangements based on individual circumstances.

    Since employment will be more disruptive, should we protect and provide even more in the form of unemployment insurance, as suggested by Mr Chew Heng Ching? He asked whether MOM has studied this. Yes. Other countries that have instituted unemployment insurance have regretted doing so. As expected, there were abuses. In Japan, the claim rate in a recession is so overwhelming that the scheme has become a severe financial burden to the state. There is a moral hazard inherent in unemployment insurance. In Canada, 'brunching' occurs - brunch, between breakfast and lunch. Workers abuse and game the system by working for the minimal qualifying period and then resign to claim the unemployment insurance benefits. The well-intentioned unemployment insurance system deteriorates into unemployment handouts.
2.00 pm

    I am aware of the counter argument of those who say that having seen and presumably learnt from the mistakes of others, we can craft our own version to avoid the pitfalls by tying up unemployment insurance with job search, training, etc. This argument is enticing, but we should remain wary.

    It reminds me of the latent alcoholic who rationalises that since most alcoholics are addicted to hard liquor, he would remain immune if he stuck to fine wines. The latent alcoholic would be quite wrong, and with devastating consequences. Once introduced, unemployment insurance would be difficult to roll back. MOM's view is that we should avoid introducing unemployment insurance at present.

Column: 1587



    Members have quite rightly pointed out that we need to enhance the employability of older workers. I agree with Mr Seng Han Thong, Ms Irene Ng and Mdm Ho Geok Choo that negative attitudes towards older workers are unwarranted and unjustified. Mr Seng remains puzzled about how the age barrier for a mature worker got shifted from 60 to 50, and now rests at 40 years old. I am equally puzzled and I am not sure how the age 40 cropped out. I thought perhaps because we started our People-for-Jobs Traineeship at that age. But we chose that age 40 barrier to compensate in part for the seniority-based wage system, where older workers found it harder to compete with younger counterparts commanding a lower salary. We certainly did not mean to send the message that at 40 your brains go ga-ga and your body goes goo-goo. This myth flies against the face of reality where, as Mdm Ho and Ms Irene Ng rightly pointed out, many workers because of their skill sets, experience and networking, peak at that age. Sir, at this juncture I have to confess that I have a vested interest in supporting this argument. But I am sure that if I put the motion to this House that life begins at 40, the ayes will have it. Many here, who are above 40, will confidently attest that they are better now than they were 10 years ago.

    On a more serious note, no single remedy will quite work as the difficulty for older workers finding re-employment is multi-faceted. To quote my Minister, there is "no single magic bullet' and we will have to approach this problem holistically.     Sir, let me now take the questions raised on rising prices of HDB flats and the related issues of affordability. I believe this was raised by Dr Tan Cheng Bock, Mr Iswaran, Dr Michael Lim, Encik Othman Haron Eusofe and several others. Let me, first of all, reiterate that affordability has been and will always continue to be a primary consideration in the pricing of new HDB flats. We have publicly stated that the Government will price new HDB flats such that 90% of Singaporeans can afford at least a 3-room flat and 70% can afford at least a 4-room flat. In other words, when we talk about affordability, this means that the maximum mortgage instalments that a family has to pay to buy either a 3-room or a 4-room flat will not exceed 40% of its monthly household income. This is the guideline that HDB uses which, I believe, is a prudential norm which is also used by other institutions. But in actual fact, even though we use the 40% rule as the norm, in reality, most buyers of our flats today, the 4-room and 5-room flats, do not use more than 25-26% of their household income.     Of course, when we are talking about pricing, we also have to take into account certain micro features, like individual attributes of the flats, facing, floor level, and so on.     Let me take you back to the time when property prices shot up in the mid-90s as a result of excessive speculation, as Mr Inderjit Singh pointed out just now. When property prices shot up in the mid-90s, HDB new flat prices lagged the market, in other words, it increased more slowly than the market. Between 1992 and 1996, resale flat prices tripled, went up by more than 200%, while new flat prices increased less than 50%. While the resale prices were going up like that, the HDB increased its new flat prices by much less. Why? Because it wanted to ensure that flat prices would not rise beyond the reach of the people, to keep them affordable.

If you go back to the peak in 1996, and you compare with today, resale prices have fallen by about 30%, but new flat prices have been adjusted downwards, on an average by about 10-15%. So prices of HDB flats are coming down, they are not increasing, as Mr Othman suggested just now.
